exercise_bank.description: Dysarthria speech therapy exercises for ElevenLabs Conversational AI - Reorganized by practical categories

everyday_scenarios.name: Everyday Scenarios
everyday_scenarios.description: Real-world communication situations for practical speech therapy application

exercises.title: Simple Coffee Order
exercises.instruction: Practice ordering coffee clearly and politely
exercises.content: I would like a coffee, please. Medium size. With cream. Thank you.
exercises.tips: Speak slowly and clearly. Make eye contact if in person.

exercises.title: Detailed Coffee Order
exercises.instruction: Order coffee with specific preferences and modifications
exercises.content: Good morning. I'd like a large cappuccino with oat milk, one sugar, and could I get that extra hot please?
exercises.tips: Group your requests logically - size, drink type, modifications

exercises.title: Coffee Shop Problem Solving
exercises.instruction: Handle a problem with your coffee order professionally
exercises.content: Excuse me, I ordered a cappuccino but this looks like a regular coffee. Could you please check my order?
exercises.tips: Stay polite but be clear about the issue

exercises.title: Restaurant Greeting
exercises.instruction: Communicate with restaurant host upon arrival
exercises.content: Hello. Table for two, please. We have a reservation under Johnson.
exercises.tips: State your needs clearly and provide necessary information

exercises.title: Menu Order
exercises.instruction: Order a complete meal at a restaurant
exercises.content: I'll have the grilled chicken with rice and vegetables. Could I get the sauce on the side? And a water to drink, please.
exercises.tips: Order main item first, then modifications, then drink

exercises.title: Dietary Restrictions
exercises.instruction: Communicate dietary needs and ask questions about menu items
exercises.content: I have a gluten allergy. Which of your pasta dishes can be made gluten-free? Is there any cross-contamination in the kitchen?
exercises.tips: Be specific about allergies - this is safety communication

exercises.title: Food Service Complaint
exercises.instruction: Address a problem with your meal professionally
exercises.content: I'm sorry, but my chicken is undercooked. Could you please have the kitchen prepare a new one? I'd appreciate it being cooked thoroughly.
exercises.tips: Be firm but polite. Food safety is important.

exercises.title: Basic Phone Greeting
exercises.instruction: Answer the phone professionally and personally
exercises.content: Hello, this is Sarah. How can I help you? Sure, let me get that information for you.
exercises.tips: Speak slightly louder and clearer on phone calls

exercises.title: Making an Appointment
exercises.instruction: Schedule a doctor's appointment over the phone
exercises.content: I'd like to schedule an appointment with Dr. Smith. I'm available Tuesday or Wednesday morning. What times do you have open?
exercises.tips: Have your calendar ready and speak your availability clearly

exercises.title: Customer Service Call
exercises.instruction: Call customer service to resolve a billing issue
exercises.content: I'm calling about my account number 12345. There's a charge on my bill I don't recognize. Can you help me understand what this is for?
exercises.tips: Have your account information ready and explain the issue clearly

exercises.title: Casual Introduction
exercises.instruction: Introduce yourself in a social setting
exercises.content: Hi, I'm Mike. Nice to meet you. I work downtown at the bank. How do you know Sarah?
exercises.tips: Include your name, a bit about yourself, and a connecting question

exercises.title: Professional Introduction
exercises.instruction: Introduce yourself in a business setting
exercises.content: Good morning, I'm Jennifer Smith from the marketing department. I'm here for the 9 AM meeting about the new product launch.
exercises.tips: Include full name, department/company, and purpose of meeting

exercises.title: Networking Introduction
exercises.instruction: Introduce yourself at a professional networking event
exercises.content: Hello, I'm David Chen. I'm a software engineer with ten years experience in mobile app development. I'm particularly interested in healthcare technology.
exercises.tips: Name, profession, experience level, and specific interest area

exercises.title: Medical Office Check-in
exercises.instruction: Practice routine check-in at a doctor's office
exercises.content: Hello, I'm here for my annual check-up with Dr. Johnson. My name is Susan Brown. Here's my insurance card.
exercises.tips: State appointment type, doctor name, your name, and have documents ready

exercises.title: Updating Medical Information
exercises.instruction: Provide routine updates to medical office staff
exercises.content: My address is still the same. My phone number changed to 555-0123. I'm still taking the same medications. No new allergies.
exercises.tips: Keep medical updates clear and organized

exercises.title: Scheduling Follow-up
exercises.instruction: Schedule a routine follow-up appointment
exercises.content: I need to schedule my next check-up in six months. I prefer morning appointments. Tuesday or Wednesday works best for me.
exercises.tips: State timeframe, preferences, and availability clearly

exercises.title: Brief Self-Introduction
exercises.instruction: Give a 30-second introduction about yourself
exercises.content: Hi, I'm Michael. I work as a teacher at the local elementary school. I've been teaching for eight years and I love working with children.
exercises.tips: Include name, profession, experience, and what you enjoy

exercises.title: Professional Elevator Pitch
exercises.instruction: Give a professional introduction in a networking setting
exercises.content: I'm Sarah Chen, a marketing coordinator with five years of experience. I specialize in social media campaigns and enjoy helping businesses connect with their customers.
exercises.tips: Name, role, experience, specialization, and passion

exercises.title: Personal Interest Pitch
exercises.instruction: Share your background and interests in a social setting
exercises.content: I'm David, originally from Chicago but I've lived here for ten years. I work in IT and in my free time I love hiking and photography. I'm always looking for new trails to explore.
exercises.tips: Include background, current situation, and personal interests

exercises.title: Talking About Family
exercises.instruction: Share information about your family in casual conversation
exercises.content: I have two kids - Emma is seven and loves soccer, and Jake is ten and enjoys reading. My spouse works downtown at the hospital. We've been married for twelve years.
exercises.tips: Share positive details about family members and relationships

exercises.title: Family Activities
exercises.instruction: Describe fun activities you do with your family
exercises.content: Last weekend we went to the zoo and the kids loved seeing the elephants. We often have movie nights on Fridays. This summer we're planning a camping trip to the mountains.
exercises.tips: Focus on enjoyable experiences and future plans

exercises.title: Morning Routine Description
exercises.instruction: Describe your typical morning routine
exercises.content: I usually wake up at seven o'clock. First I have coffee and check the news. Then I shower and get dressed. I eat breakfast and leave for work by eight-thirty.
exercises.tips: Use time markers and sequence words like 'first,' 'then,' 'finally'

exercises.title: Evening Activities
exercises.instruction: Share what you typically do in the evenings
exercises.content: After work I like to take a walk around the neighborhood. I usually cook dinner around six o'clock. Then I spend time with my family, read, or watch a good movie.
exercises.tips: Include both routine activities and leisure time

exercises.title: Weekend Activities
exercises.instruction: Describe your weekend plans or activities
exercises.content: This Saturday I'm meeting friends for brunch downtown. Sunday I plan to work in my garden and maybe visit my parents. I'm looking forward to relaxing and catching up with people.
exercises.tips: Include both social activities and personal time

exercises.title: Sharing Hobbies and Interests
exercises.instruction: Talk about your hobbies and why you enjoy them
exercises.content: I'm really into photography, especially nature photography. I love being outdoors and capturing beautiful moments. Last month I took some amazing sunset photos at the lake. It's very relaxing for me.
exercises.tips: Explain what you do and why you enjoy it

exercises.title: Where I'm From
exercises.instruction: Share information about your hometown or background
exercises.content: I grew up in a small town in Ohio. It was a great place to be a kid - very safe and everyone knew each other. I moved here for college and decided to stay because I love the city life.
exercises.tips: Include positive memories and explain your current location choice

exercises.title: Personal Accomplishments
exercises.instruction: Share something you're proud of accomplishing
exercises.content: Last year I completed my first 5K run. I had never been much of a runner, but I trained for three months. Crossing the finish line felt amazing and now I run regularly.
exercises.tips: Include the challenge, effort, and positive outcome

exercises.title: Favorite Foods and Cooking
exercises.instruction: Talk about your favorite foods or cooking experiences
exercises.content: I love trying different types of cuisine. My favorite is Italian food - especially homemade pasta. I enjoy cooking on weekends and trying new recipes. Last week I made a delicious lasagna.
exercises.tips: Share what you like and any personal experiences

exercises.title: Travel Stories
exercises.instruction: Share a positive travel experience or dream destination
exercises.content: My best vacation was visiting San Francisco last summer. We rode the cable cars, visited Fisherman's Wharf, and had amazing seafood. The Golden Gate Bridge was even more beautiful in person. I'd love to go back someday.
exercises.tips: Include specific details and positive emotions

exercises.title: Favorite Season Activities
exercises.instruction: Talk about activities you enjoy during different seasons
exercises.content: Fall is my favorite season because the weather is perfect for hiking. I love seeing the leaves change colors. We usually go apple picking with the kids and make pies together. It's such a fun family tradition.
exercises.tips: Connect seasonal activities with family or personal enjoyment

naming_pronunciation.name: Naming & Pronunciation
naming_pronunciation.description: Articulation exercises based on clinical speech therapy hierarchy for dysarthria

exercises.title: P Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice the P sound at the beginning of words. Focus on lip closure and release
exercises.content: Pay. Put. Pen. Pop. Pack. Pan. Pet. Pot. Pit. Pad.
exercises.tips: Press lips together firmly, then release with a small puff of air

exercises.title: B Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice the B sound with voice. Feel the vibration in your throat
exercises.content: Bay. But. Ben. Bob. Back. Ban. Bet. Bot. Bit. Bad.
exercises.tips: Same lip position as P, but add voice vibration

exercises.title: T Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice T sound with tongue tip touching roof of mouth
exercises.content: Tea. Top. Ten. Tip. Tap. Tie. Toy. Two. Toe. Tab.
exercises.tips: Touch tongue tip to the ridge behind your upper teeth

exercises.title: D Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice D sound with voice and tongue contact
exercises.content: Day. Dog. Den. Dip. Dad. Do. Dot. Dig. Door. Duck.
exercises.tips: Same tongue position as T, but add voice vibration

exercises.title: K Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice K sound with back of tongue touching soft palate
exercises.content: Key. Cat. Cup. Can. Car. Come. Cut. Call. Keep. Cap.
exercises.tips: Raise back of tongue to touch the soft part of the roof of your mouth

exercises.title: G Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice G sound with voice and tongue contact
exercises.content: Go. Get. Guy. Got. Gap. Game. Give. Good. Gas. Gun.
exercises.tips: Same tongue position as K, but add voice vibration

exercises.title: F Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice F sound with bottom lip touching upper teeth
exercises.content: Fee. Fat. Fun. Fit. Fog. Fan. Fish. Fast. Face. Fire.
exercises.tips: Lightly bite your lower lip with upper teeth and blow air

exercises.title: V Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice V sound with voice and lip-tooth contact
exercises.content: Very. Van. Vote. Vet. Voice. View. Vine. Vase. Vest. Vast.
exercises.tips: Same lip position as F, but add voice vibration

exercises.title: S Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice S sound with tongue creating a narrow groove
exercises.content: See. Say. Sit. Sun. Sip. Sad. Side. Sell. Sing. Soap.
exercises.tips: Make a groove with your tongue and blow air through it

exercises.title: Z Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice Z sound with voice and tongue groove
exercises.content: Zoo. Zip. Zone. Zero. Zap. Zoom. Zest. Zinc. Zeal. Zen.
exercises.tips: Same tongue position as S, but add voice vibration

exercises.title: SH Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice SH sound with lips rounded and tongue pulled back
exercises.content: She. Ship. Shop. Shoe. Shut. Shake. Shirt. Sheep. Shine. Sharp.
exercises.tips: Round your lips slightly and pull tongue back from S position

exercises.title: ZH Sound - Middle Position
exercises.instruction: Practice the ZH sound as in 'measure' in the middle of words
exercises.content: Measure. Leisure. Pleasure. Treasure. Vision. Decision. Revision. Fusion. Conclusion. Occasion.
exercises.tips: Same position as SH but add voice vibration

exercises.title: CH Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice CH sound combining T and SH sounds
exercises.content: Cheese. Chair. Chain. Chip. Chop. Choose. Check. Chin. Chest. Cheap.
exercises.tips: Start with tongue in T position, then move to SH

exercises.title: J Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice J sound combining D and ZH sounds with voice
exercises.content: Juice. Jump. Just. Jam. Job. Joy. Joke. Jar. Jet. Jog.
exercises.tips: Start with tongue in D position, then move to ZH with voice

exercises.title: TH Sound (voiceless) - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice unvoiced TH with tongue between teeth
exercises.content: Think. Thank. Thick. Thin. Throw. Three. Through. Thirty. Thirst. Thumb.
exercises.tips: Place tongue tip between teeth and blow air

exercises.title: TH Sound (voiced) - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice voiced TH with tongue between teeth and voice
exercises.content: The. This. That. They. There. Then. These. Those. Though. Than.
exercises.tips: Same tongue position as voiceless TH, but add voice vibration

exercises.title: R Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice R sound without tongue touching roof of mouth
exercises.content: Red. Run. Road. Rain. Ring. Rock. Room. Ride. Rich. Rice.
exercises.tips: Curl tongue tip up but don't touch the roof of your mouth

exercises.title: L Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice L sound with tongue tip touching alveolar ridge
exercises.content: Lee. Let. Light. Love. Look. Live. Low. Leg. Lip. Lake.
exercises.tips: Touch tongue tip to ridge behind upper teeth, air flows around sides

exercises.title: M Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice M sound with lips closed and voice through nose
exercises.content: Me. My. Make. More. Man. Mom. Move. Moon. Mail. Meet.
exercises.tips: Close lips and let voice come through your nose

exercises.title: N Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice N sound with tongue tip up and voice through nose
exercises.content: No. New. Name. Now. Nice. Need. Never. Next. Note. Near.
exercises.tips: Touch tongue tip to alveolar ridge, voice through nose

exercises.title: NG Sound - Ending Position
exercises.instruction: Practice NG sound with back of tongue up and voice through nose
exercises.content: Ring. Sing. Long. Strong. Young. Thing. Bring. King. Wing. Hang.
exercises.tips: Raise back of tongue to soft palate, voice through nose

exercises.title: W Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice W sound with rounded lips and voice
exercises.content: We. Way. Win. Work. Water. Want. Wait. Walk. Warm. Watch.
exercises.tips: Round lips as if saying 'oo' then glide to next vowel

exercises.title: Y Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice Y sound with tongue high and forward
exercises.content: Yes. You. Year. Young. Your. Yet. Yard. Yellow. Yell. Yeast.
exercises.tips: Raise tongue toward hard palate as if saying 'ee'

exercises.title: H Sound - Beginning Position
exercises.instruction: Practice H sound with open throat and breath flow
exercises.content: He. Hi. Hat. Home. House. Hand. Head. Heart. Hope. Help.
exercises.tips: Open throat and breathe out with voice

exercises.title: P Sound - Ending Position
exercises.instruction: Practice P sound at the end of words with clear closure
exercises.content: Cup. Map. Top. Ship. Lap. Deep. Keep. Stop. Shop. Tape.
exercises.tips: End with lips pressed together firmly

exercises.title: T Sound - Ending Position
exercises.instruction: Practice T sound at the end of words with tongue contact
exercises.content: Cat. Hat. Sit. Get. Put. Cut. Bat. Hot. Fit. Net.
exercises.tips: End with tongue tip touching alveolar ridge

exercises.title: K Sound - Ending Position
exercises.instruction: Practice K sound at the end of words with back tongue contact
exercises.content: Book. Look. Make. Take. Like. Back. Rock. Sick. Talk. Walk.
exercises.tips: End with back of tongue touching soft palate

exercises.title: Beginning Consonant Clusters
exercises.instruction: Practice two consonant sounds together at word beginnings
exercises.content: Blue. Green. Play. Stop. Train. Dress. Frog. Swim. Clap. Grab.
exercises.tips: Practice each consonant clearly but blend them smoothly

exercises.title: Ending Consonant Clusters
exercises.instruction: Practice consonant clusters at the end of words
exercises.content: Fast. Best. Just. Last. First. Next. Desk. Task. Twist. Lift.
exercises.tips: Make sure both final consonants are heard clearly

exercises.title: Three Consonant Clusters
exercises.instruction: Practice three consonant sounds together at word beginnings
exercises.content: Street. Strong. Spring. Splash. Scream. Spray. Strap. Throw. Scratch. Split.
exercises.tips: Take your time and articulate each consonant within the cluster

exercises.title: P vs B Minimal Pairs
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between P and B sounds
exercises.content: Pay - Bay. Pen - Ben. Pat - Bat. Pet - Bet. Pig - Big. Pack - Back.
exercises.tips: P has no voice, B has voice vibration

exercises.title: T vs D Minimal Pairs
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between T and D sounds
exercises.content: Ten - Den. Tie - Die. Toe - Dough. Two - Do. Town - Down. Tear - Dear.
exercises.tips: T has no voice, D has voice vibration

exercises.title: K vs G Minimal Pairs
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between K and G sounds
exercises.content: Come - Gum. Card - Guard. Call - Gall. Cold - Gold. Coat - Goat. Cut - Gut.
exercises.tips: K has no voice, G has voice vibration

exercises.title: F vs V Minimal Pairs
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between F and V sounds
exercises.content: Fan - Van. Fine - Vine. Fast - Vast. Feel - Veal. Fairy - Very. Face - Vase.
exercises.tips: F has no voice, V has voice vibration

exercises.title: S vs Z Minimal Pairs
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between S and Z sounds
exercises.content: Sue - Zoo. Sip - Zip. Seal - Zeal. Sap - Zap. Sink - Zinc. Sun - None with Z.
exercises.tips: S has no voice, Z has voice vibration

exercises.title: TH Voiceless vs Voiced
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between the two TH sounds
exercises.content: Think - This. Thank - Than. Thick - That. Thigh - Thy. Through - Those.
exercises.tips: First TH has no voice, second TH has voice vibration

exercises.title: R vs L Minimal Pairs
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between R and L sounds
exercises.content: Red - Led. Right - Light. Rock - Lock. Road - Load. Race - Lace. Rain - Lane.
exercises.tips: R curls up without touching, L touches alveolar ridge

exercises.title: Two Syllable Words
exercises.instruction: Practice clear pronunciation of two syllable words
exercises.content: Water. Paper. Table. Simple. Happy. Garden. Kitchen. Window. Doctor. Sister.
exercises.tips: Make each syllable clear and distinct

exercises.title: Three Syllable Words
exercises.instruction: Practice clear pronunciation of three syllable words
exercises.content: Computer. Hospital. Beautiful. Important. Telephone. Remember. Together. Tomorrow. Family. Animal.
exercises.tips: Break words into syllables: com-pu-ter

exercises.title: Four Syllable Words
exercises.instruction: Practice clear pronunciation of four syllable words
exercises.content: Television. Information. Communication. Conversation. University. Laboratory. Emergency. Photography. Democracy. Electricity.
exercises.tips: Practice slowly first: tel-e-vi-sion

exercises.title: Short Vowel Contrasts
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between short vowel sounds
exercises.content: Bit - Bet - Bat. Hit - Hot - Hat. Sit - Set - Sat. Pit - Pet - Pat.
exercises.tips: Make each vowel sound distinct and clear

exercises.title: Long Vowel Contrasts
exercises.instruction: Practice distinguishing between long vowel sounds
exercises.content: Beat - Boot - Boat. Seat - Suit - Coat. Heat - Hoot - Note. Feet - Food - Fold.
exercises.tips: Long vowels should be held longer and be very clear

exercises.title: Diphthong Sounds
exercises.instruction: Practice vowel sounds that glide from one to another
exercises.content: Boy. Toy. Joy. Coin. Point. House. Mouse. Loud. Cloud. Round.
exercises.tips: Let your mouth move smoothly from first vowel to second

exercises.title: Word Stress Patterns
exercises.instruction: Practice emphasizing the correct syllable in words
exercises.content: TAble. comPUter. BEAutiful. imPORtant. HOSpital. teleVIsion.
exercises.tips: Make the stressed syllable louder and longer

exercises.title: Word Combinations
exercises.instruction: Practice clear articulation in connected speech
exercises.content: Red car. Big dog. Hot coffee. Nice day. Good morning. Thank you. See you later. How are you?
exercises.tips: Keep each word clear but connect them naturally

voice_control_pitch.name: Voice Control & Pitch
voice_control_pitch.description: Exercises focusing on volume control, pitch variation, and voice quality improvement

exercises.title: Volume Control - Quiet to Loud
exercises.instruction: Say 'hello' starting quietly, then gradually getting louder with each repetition
exercises.content: Hello... Hello... HELLO... HELLO... hello.
exercises.tips: Control your volume deliberately, don't shout

exercises.title: High to Low Pitch
exercises.instruction: Say 'good morning' starting with a high pitch, then gradually lower your pitch
exercises.content: Good morning... good morning... good morning... good morning.
exercises.tips: Let your voice naturally rise and fall

exercises.title: Question Voice Pattern
exercises.instruction: Practice asking questions with rising pitch at the end
exercises.content: How are you? What time is it? Where are you going? Are you ready?
exercises.tips: Let your voice rise naturally at the end of questions

exercises.title: Expressing Excitement
exercises.instruction: Show excitement in your voice while maintaining clarity
exercises.content: That's wonderful news! I'm so happy for you! This is amazing! What a great surprise!
exercises.tips: Use pitch and volume changes to show emotion

exercises.title: Serious Communication
exercises.instruction: Practice speaking with a serious, authoritative tone
exercises.content: This is important information. Please listen carefully. We need to discuss this matter. Take this seriously.
exercises.tips: Lower pitch and steady volume convey seriousness

exercises.title: Controlled Whispering
exercises.instruction: Practice whispering clearly while maintaining articulation
exercises.content: Can you hear me? This is a secret. Come closer. Listen carefully.
exercises.tips: Even when whispering, maintain clear consonants

exercises.title: Phone Voice Clarity
exercises.instruction: Practice phone voice with appropriate volume and clarity
exercises.content: Hello, this is Sarah calling. Could I speak with the manager please? I have a question about my account.
exercises.tips: Phone conversations need slightly more volume and clarity

exercises.title: Narrative Voice Variety
exercises.instruction: Tell a story using different voices for different parts
exercises.content: Once upon a time... [gentle voice] there was a loud giant... [deep voice] and a tiny mouse... [soft voice] who became friends.
exercises.tips: Use voice changes to make stories more engaging

exercises.title: Yes and No Variations
exercises.instruction: Say yes and no with different emotions and pitch patterns
exercises.content: Yes! [excited] Yes. [calm] No! [firm] No... [disappointed] Maybe? [uncertain]
exercises.tips: Let your voice show your feelings

exercises.title: Public Speaking Voice
exercises.instruction: Practice speaking to a group with appropriate projection and variation
exercises.content: Good morning everyone. Today I want to share some exciting news. Our project has been very successful.
exercises.tips: Project your voice without shouting, vary your pitch

exercises.title: Soothing Speech
exercises.instruction: Practice speaking in a comforting, gentle tone
exercises.content: Everything will be okay. Don't worry about it. You're doing great. I'm here to help.
exercises.tips: Use a lower, softer voice for comfort

exercises.title: Controlled Disagreement
exercises.instruction: Express disagreement firmly but respectfully without raising voice
exercises.content: I disagree with that point. I see it differently. That's not quite right. Let me explain my view.
exercises.tips: Stay firm but avoid aggressive volume or pitch

exercises.title: Getting Attention
exercises.instruction: Practice calling someone's attention appropriately
exercises.content: Excuse me! [polite] Hey there! [friendly] Attention please! [formal] Over here! [casual]
exercises.tips: Match your voice to the social situation

exercises.title: Expressive Reading
exercises.instruction: Read with expression, varying your voice for punctuation
exercises.content: What a beautiful day! The sun is shining. Are we going to the park? I hope so...
exercises.tips: Let punctuation guide your voice changes

exercises.title: Professional Service Voice
exercises.instruction: Practice customer service voice - friendly, helpful, clear
exercises.content: Good morning! How can I help you today? I'd be happy to assist you. Is there anything else?
exercises.tips: Sound helpful and approachable through your voice

exercises.title: Showing Surprise
exercises.instruction: Express surprise with appropriate voice changes
exercises.content: Really? [curious] Oh my! [surprised] I can't believe it! [amazed] No way! [shocked]
exercises.tips: Use pitch jumps and volume changes to show surprise

exercises.title: Educational Instruction
exercises.instruction: Practice teaching voice with clear emphasis and variation
exercises.content: First, remember this key point. Second, notice the difference here. Finally, let's review what we learned.
exercises.tips: Emphasize important words and use pauses effectively

exercises.title: Different Greeting Styles
exercises.instruction: Say greetings with different energy levels and tones
exercises.content: Hi there! [energetic] Good morning. [calm] Hello friend. [warm] Hey! [casual]
exercises.tips: Match your voice energy to your relationship with the person

exercises.title: Emotional Description
exercises.instruction: Describe feelings while showing them in your voice
exercises.content: I'm feeling happy today. I'm a bit worried about tomorrow. I'm excited about the weekend. I'm tired right now.
exercises.tips: Let your voice match the emotion you're describing

exercises.title: Sincere Compliments
exercises.instruction: Give compliments with warm, genuine voice tone
exercises.content: You look wonderful today. That was really well done. I'm impressed with your work. You have a great smile.
exercises.tips: Compliments should sound warm and genuine
